title: Nigeria Pharmacy Registry — Data Source Catalog
description: Catalog of potential and active data sources for pharmacy/PPMV location ingestion. Each entry tracks provenance, licensing, and ingestion status.

sources.license: Google Maps Platform Terms of Service — display only, no redistribution of raw data
sources.coverage_scope: National — commercial pharmacy listings indexed by Google
sources.quality_notes: High-quality geocoded listings from Google's commercial database. Strong urban coverage, phone numbers often available. Business status (open/closed) is a valuable signal. Duplicate detection needed against OSM and GRID3 records. Google place_id is a stable external identifier.
sources.notes: Fetched via Places API (New) Nearby Search with grid-search strategy. Each request covers a 25km radius circle, ~1,200 grid points for national coverage. Cost: ~$0.032 per request. API key required (enable Places API New in Google Cloud Console). Google place_id is a stable identifier useful for cross-referencing.

sources.quality_notes: Most comprehensive open spatial dataset for Nigeria health facilities. Pharmacy/PPMV subset must be filtered from broader health facility data. Coordinates generally reliable but some records lack precise geocoding.
sources.notes: GRID3 is a collaboration between the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, WorldPop, and the Nigerian government. The dataset is periodically updated. Filter by facility_type to extract pharmacy-relevant records.

sources.coverage_scope: National — coverage uneven, stronger in urban areas (Lagos, Abuja, Port Harcourt)
sources.quality_notes: Community-contributed data. Names may be inconsistent. Urban areas have much better coverage than rural. Some duplicate entries possible. Coordinates are generally accurate where present.
sources.notes: Extract via Overpass API. Use both amenity=pharmacy and healthcare=pharmacy tags. PPMVs are rarely tagged distinctly in OSM — most will appear under generic pharmacy tags.

sources.license: Government of Nigeria — public registry (no explicit open license)
sources.quality_notes: Authoritative for accredited facilities but list may lag behind actual accreditation status. No geocoordinates — geocoding required. Facility names may differ from signage. PPMVs are generally not included.
sources.notes: NHIA facility codes are critical external identifiers for interoperability. Data is not openly downloadable — requires partnership or scraping of published lists. Coordinate with Agent 8 (Regulatory Integration) for formal data-sharing agreement.

sources.license: Government of Nigeria — regulatory register (restricted access)
sources.format: Unknown — likely Excel/CSV periodic dump or API
sources.quality_notes: Gold-standard regulatory source for pharmacy registration status. No geocoordinates. Registration status may lag (expired licenses still listed). Includes both pharmacies and PPMVs with distinct category codes.
sources.notes: PCN premises registration number is the most important external identifier. Data access requires formal partnership — see Agent 8. PCN distinguishes between Community Pharmacy, Hospital Pharmacy, and PPMV categories.

sources.quality_notes: NAFDAC licensing data complements PCN registration. Some overlap with PCN dataset expected. Geocoding required.
sources.notes: NAFDAC license number is a valuable external identifier for cross-referencing. Data access requires partnership. Lower priority than PCN since PCN is the primary pharmacy regulator.

sources.coverage_scope: Varies by partner — typically urban and peri-urban
sources.quality_notes: Fintech agent networks (Flutterwave, OPay, PalmPay) and MNOs (MTN MoMo) maintain pharmacy/PPMV location data for their agent networks. Quality varies. May include pharmacies that double as mobile money agents.
sources.notes: Exploratory source. Requires commercial partnership. Useful for filling coverage gaps, especially for PPMVs in underserved areas. Coordinate with Agent 8 for partnership approach.

sources.source_name: State Ministry of Health Facility Lists
sources.quality_notes: State-level datasets vary significantly in quality and completeness. Some states maintain digital records, others have paper-only registers. Geocoding required.
sources.notes: Incremental ingestion strategy: start with pilot states (Lagos, FCT, Kano) then expand. Coordinate with state pharmacists' councils where possible.

sources.quality_notes: Quality depends on collector training. GPS accuracy varies by device. Photos provide evidence for L2 verification. Duplicate submissions likely — feed into deduplication pipeline.
sources.notes: Future data source. Requires mobile data collection tool setup (KoboToolbox or custom app). Each submission creates an L0 record with photo evidence that can fast-track to L2. Collector ID enables accountability.
